So we're talking about revenue recognition, cost Recognition.
The big thing here is the difference is you really don't need to manage your WIP account for imbalances anymore.
In netsuite, the imbalances are going to show up in the accrued purchases account.
So in that white paper that we gave you, it talks about really the item receipt that's going to impact the WIP account.
And then it's when the product is recognized as a cost, and that is when it's fulfilled or leaves your warehouse, that's when the cost is recognized.

And so, and then we do some things in addition there to make sure that if there's some timing issues, you can, the system will prompt you to generate some journal entries to accrue revenue or cost to make sure that you're meeting that gap requirement of timing.
So I don't know how deep you're able to go into that.
Lorraine, if you have any other questions about that, but that's usually one of the deeper questions that we have from dealers coming off core, because it is different.
Because I think, guys, it hits whip when the vendor bill comes in.
Or.
The vendor invoice, if I'm correct.
Yeah, inherently it makes sense to me.
Obviously, it's just a matter of, you know, changing now how we analyze WIP and how we're cleaning that up and making sure we're leaving that when we invoice.
But now you're saying it's going to be through the accrued purchases account.
So I think we have the same work, it's just in a different account.
And then the other thing that we did is we built a utility called Cost Variance and Recognition Utility.
And so what that does is it searches the system and really the accrued purchases account to see if there are any imbalances.
So a good example of an imbalance would be, all right, my purchase order, I ordered an item on my PO for $100.
When I generated my item receipt, it inherited that cost from the PO.
So the item receipt came in at $100.
And then when I got my vendor bill, the vendor bill came in at 150.
There was a $50 difference.
So I created an issue record because I wanted to find out, well, hey, we got a price discrepancy.
I got to figure this out.
And we did our investigation and we found out, yeah, actually it does cost $150.
Now, I know that's somewhat rare, but this is the kind of scenario I'm talking about.
But the item receipt impacted the accrued purchases at only $100.
So we generate the, you know, the vendor bill.
We have an imbalance of $50.
So our tool finds all of those imbalances and will automatically create the journal entry to recognize cost.
And you want, you're going to want to run that at the end of the month, so it's happening in the same period.
And it'll post those vendor variances via journal entry to recognize costs and it tags the project.
And actually I wrote that down that we have to write off any variances, any variance balance at the end of the month.
So is that going to be automatically done or.
We have to do it.
You have to do it.
Okay.
Yeah.
It'll be kind of one of your end of the month tasks.
It is something that we can automate.

And that's okay.

So I do.

It does.
Okay.

Largely.
Yeah, it's largely an honor system now.

But it would be nice to have better guardrails in place to make sure it's happening.

You'll be able to do that.

Like I said, this is.
This is typically for dealers coming off core.
There's usually a lot of questions around this.
So don't hesitate.
We expect more and we'll be happy to do some more explaining as well.

The one thing I would say about this though is your WIP account, which I know your bank looks at and I think you can borrow against, that's probably going to be impacted earlier in the process than what it is now because it's going to be.
The item receipt is going to be incrementing that account.
Yeah, no bank doesn't look at our WIP anymore.
They, they actually just look at our backlog.
So we change that metric.
So WIP is no longer on the table.
So that's very interesting.
So for the sake of the transcript, so we.
That's definitely a key finding associated with KBM is that WIP is not as important as the backlog.
So we need a lot of clarity on the backlog.
So with that in mind, before we jump into the next topic, let me ask you a couple questions about your backlog.
Some dealers define it differently.
Let me throw out a definition.
You tell me, yay or nay.
Backlog is everything on a sales order that is not yet invoiced.
Is that your definition?
Yeah.
Yes.
Yeah.
Quotes don't.
Quotes do not impact backlog.
Those are potential backlog, but they aren't backlog.
Don't hit backlog until they've been converted to an open order or whatever Orion calls it.
We call them an order.
Yep.
But yes, we have the same definition.
Would it also be valuable for you to see a backlog by vendor?
Sure.
Yeah.
That's hard to get right now.
Yeah, that'd be great.

We don't analyze it per se too much, again because of the lack of visibility to it.
But obviously we're just looking at it in totality and looking what's coming down the pipe, you know, the pipeline.
And that's what we're looking at.
I use it to do my forecasting, you know, like what month and what I'm going to bill and things like that for it.
So.
But the granular level of what's in the backlog, we don't do too much.

Kevin does a little bit more because he's drilling down and he's pulling out the margin of those projects so that again from my forecast I can pull that in and I share that with Matt and Mark so that they also know what's coming and what it looks like.

That approval.
There's two different ways to do this.
You can, you can use the NetSuite native approval process and if you enter a bill into the system and it's pending approval, it has no GL impact.
So it doesn't show up on your AP aging from a cash flow forecast.
It's not considered all of that.
Or you can enter it and put it on payment hold.
And it does have a GL impact, but it won't allow anybody to pay it.
So there's really kind of two ways that you can do this.
And the reason why you would maybe not bring it in as an approved state is there might be a discrepancy.
But the idea here is if somebody's processing payroll or payroll bills, they say there's a discrepancy.
I'll put it in.
I'll either say it's pending approval, no GL impact, or we don't even have the approval process turned on.
We say it's on payment hold, has an AP impact.
